content.renderedOutput:
This post is part of the InÂ­troÂ­ducÂ­tion to Vert.x seÂ­ries. So, letâ€™s have a quick look about the conÂ­tent of the preÂ­viÂ­ous posts. In the first post, we deÂ­velÂ­oped a very simÂ­ple Vert.x 3 apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion, and saw how this apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion can be tested, packÂ­aged and exÂ­eÂ­cuted. In the last post, we saw how this apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion beÂ­came conÂ­figÂ­urable and how we can use a ranÂ­dom port in test.

Well, nothÂ­ing fancyâ€¦ Letâ€™s go a bit furÂ­ther this time and deÂ­velop a CRUD-â€‹ish apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion. So an apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion exÂ­posÂ­ing an HTML page inÂ­terÂ­actÂ­ing with the backÂ­end using a REST API. The level of RESTÂ­fullÂ­ness of the API is not the topic of this post, I let you deÂ­cide as itâ€™s a very slipÂ­pery topic.

So, in other words we are going to see:

  • Vert.x Web - a frameÂ­work that let you creÂ­ate Web apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tions easÂ­ily using Vert.x
  • How to exÂ­pose staÂ­tic reÂ­sources
  • How to deÂ­velop a REST API

The code deÂ­velÂ­oped in this post is availÂ­able on the post-3 branch of this Github project. We are going to start from the post-2 codeÂ­base.

So, letâ€™s start.

Vert.x Web

As you may have noÂ­tices in the preÂ­viÂ­ous posts, dealÂ­ing with comÂ­plex HTTP apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion using only Vert.x Core would be kind of cumÂ­berÂ­some. Thatâ€™s the main reaÂ­son beÂ­hind Vert.x Web. It makes the deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment of Vert.x base web apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tions reÂ­ally easy, withÂ­out changÂ­ing the phiÂ­losÂ­oÂ­phy.

To use Vert.x Web, you need to upÂ­date the pom.xml file to add the folÂ­lowÂ­ing deÂ­penÂ­dency:

<dependency>
  <groupId>io.vertx</groupId>
  <artifactId>vertx-web</artifactId>
  <version>3.0.0</version>
</dependency>

Thatâ€™s the only thing you need to use Vert.x Web. Sweet, no ?

Letâ€™s now use it. ReÂ­memÂ­ber, in the preÂ­viÂ­ous post, when we reÂ­quested http://loÂ­calÂ­host:8080, we reply a nice Hello World mesÂ­sage. Letâ€™s do the same with Vert.x Web. Open the io.vertx.blog.first.MyFirstVerticle class and change the start method to be:

@Override
public void start(Future<Void> fut) {
 // Create a router object.
 Router router = Router.router(vertx);

 // Bind "/" to our hello message - so we are still compatible.
 router.route("/").handler(routingContext -> {
   HttpServerResponse response = routingContext.response();
   response
       .putHeader("content-type", "text/html")
       .end("<h1>Hello from my first Vert.x 3 application</h1>");
 });

 // Create the HTTP server and pass the "accept" method to the request handler.
 vertx
     .createHttpServer()
     .requestHandler(router::accept)
     .listen(
         // Retrieve the port from the configuration,
         // default to 8080.
         config().getInteger("http.port", 8080),
         result -> {
           if (result.succeeded()) {
             fut.complete();
           } else {
             fut.fail(result.cause());
           }
         }
     );
}

You may be surÂ­prise by the length of this snipÂ­pet (in comÂ­parÂ­iÂ­son to the preÂ­viÂ­ous code). But as we are going to see, it will make our app on steroids, just be paÂ­tient.

As you can see, we start by creÂ­atÂ­ing a Router obÂ­ject. The router is the corÂ­nerÂ­stone of Vert.x Web. This obÂ­ject is reÂ­sponÂ­siÂ­ble for disÂ­patchÂ­ing the HTTP reÂ­quests to the right hanÂ­dler. Two other conÂ­cepts are very imÂ­porÂ­tant in Vert.x Web:

  • Routes - which let you deÂ­fine how reÂ­quest are disÂ­patched
  • HanÂ­dlers - which are the acÂ­tual acÂ­tion proÂ­cessÂ­ing the reÂ­quests and writÂ­ing the reÂ­sult. HanÂ­dlers can be chained.

If you unÂ­derÂ­stand these 3 conÂ­cepts, you have unÂ­derÂ­stood everyÂ­thing in Vert.x Web.

Letâ€™s focus on this code first:

router.route("/").handler(routingContext -> {
  HttpServerResponse response = routingContext.response();
  response
      .putHeader("content-type", "text/html")
      .end("<h1>Hello from my first Vert.x 3 application</h1>");
});

It routes reÂ­quests arÂ­rivÂ­ing on â€/â€ to the given hanÂ­dler. HanÂ­dlers reÂ­ceive a RoutingContext obÂ­ject. This hanÂ­dler is quite simÂ­iÂ­lar to the code we had beÂ­fore, and itâ€™s quite norÂ­mal as it maÂ­nipÂ­uÂ­lates the same type of obÂ­ject: HttpServerResponse.

Letâ€™s now have a look to the rest of the code:

vertx
    .createHttpServer()
    .requestHandler(router::accept)
    .listen(
        // Retrieve the port from the configuration,
        // default to 8080.
        config().getInteger("http.port", 8080),
        result -> {
          if (result.succeeded()) {
            fut.complete();
          } else {
            fut.fail(result.cause());
          }
        }
    );
}

Itâ€™s baÂ­siÂ­cally the same code as beÂ­fore, exÂ­cept that we change the reÂ­quest hanÂ­dler. We pass router::accept to the hanÂ­dler. You may not be faÂ­milÂ­iar with this noÂ­taÂ­tion. Itâ€™s a refÂ­erÂ­ence to a method (here the method accept from the router obÂ­ject). In other worlds, it inÂ­structs vert.x to call the accept method of the router when it reÂ­ceives a reÂ­quest.

Letâ€™s try to see if this work:

mvn clean package
java -jar target/my-first-app-1.0-SNAPSHOT-fat.jar

By openÂ­ing http://localhost:8080 in your browser you should see the Hello mesÂ­sage. As we didnâ€™t change the beÂ­havÂ­ior of the apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion, our tests are still valid.

Exposing static resources

Ok, so we have a first apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion using vert.x web. Letâ€™s see some of the benÂ­eÂ­fits. Letâ€™s start with servÂ­ing staÂ­tic reÂ­sources, such as an index.html page. BeÂ­fore we go furÂ­ther, I should start with a disÂ­claimer: â€œthe HTML page we are going to see here is ugly like hell : Iâ€™m not a UI guyâ€. I should also add that there are probÂ­aÂ­bly plenty of betÂ­ter ways to imÂ­pleÂ­ment this and a myrÂ­iad of frameÂ­works I should try, but thatâ€™s not the point. I tried to keep things simÂ­ple and just reÂ­lyÂ­ing on JQuery and TwitÂ­ter BootÂ­strap, so if you know a bit of JavaScript you can unÂ­derÂ­stand and edit the page.

Letâ€™s creÂ­ate the HTML page that will be the entry point of our apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion. CreÂ­ate an index.html page in src/main/resources/assets with the conÂ­tent from here. As itâ€™s just a HTML page with a bit of JavaScript, we wonâ€™t deÂ­tail the file here. If you have quesÂ­tions, just post comÂ­ments.

BaÂ­siÂ­cally, the page is a simÂ­ple CRUD UI to manÂ­age my colÂ­lecÂ­tion of not-â€‹yet-finished botÂ­tles of Whisky. It was made in a generic way, so you can transÂ­pose it to your own colÂ­lecÂ­tion. The list of prodÂ­uct is disÂ­played in the main table. You can creÂ­ate a new prodÂ­uct, edit one or delete one. These acÂ­tions are reÂ­lyÂ­ing on a REST API (that we are going to imÂ­pleÂ­ment) through AJAX calls. Thatâ€™s all.

Once this page is creÂ­ated, edit the io.vertx.blog.first.MyFirstVerticle class and change the start method to be:

@Override
public void start(Future<Void> fut) {
 Router router = Router.router(vertx);
 router.route("/").handler(routingContext -> {
   HttpServerResponse response = routingContext.response();
   response
       .putHeader("content-type", "text/html")
       .end("<h1>Hello from my first Vert.x 3 application</h1>");
 });

 // Serve static resources from the /assets directory
 router.route("/assets/*").handler(StaticHandler.create("assets"));

 vertx
     .createHttpServer()
     .requestHandler(router::accept)
     .listen(
         // Retrieve the port from the configuration,
         // default to 8080.
         config().getInteger("http.port", 8080),
         result -> {
           if (result.succeeded()) {
             fut.complete();
           } else {
             fut.fail(result.cause());
           }
         }
     );
}

The only difÂ­ferÂ­ence with the preÂ­viÂ­ous code is the router.route("/assets/*").handler(StaticHandler.create("assets")); line. So, what does this line mean? Itâ€™s acÂ­tuÂ­ally quite simÂ­ple. It routes reÂ­quests on â€œ/asÂ­sets/*â€ to reÂ­sources stored in the â€œasÂ­setsâ€ diÂ­recÂ­tory. So our index.html page is going to be served using http://localhost:8080/assets/index.html.

BeÂ­fore testÂ­ing this, letâ€™s take a few secÂ­onds on the hanÂ­dler creÂ­ation. All proÂ­cessÂ­ing acÂ­tions in Vert.x web are imÂ­pleÂ­mented as hanÂ­dler. To creÂ­ate a hanÂ­dler you alÂ­ways call the create method.

So, Iâ€™m sure you are imÂ­paÂ­tient to see our beauÂ­tiÂ­ful HTML page. Letâ€™s build and run the apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion:

mvn clean package
java -jar target/my-first-app-1.0-SNAPSHOT-fat.jar

Now, open your browser to http://localhost:8080/assets/index.html. Here it isâ€¦ Ugly right? I told you.

As you may noÂ­tice tooâ€¦ the table is empty, this is beÂ­cause we didnâ€™t imÂ­pleÂ­ment the REST API yet. Letâ€™s do that now.

REST API with Vert.x Web

Vert.x Web makes the imÂ­pleÂ­menÂ­taÂ­tion of REST API reÂ­ally easy, as it baÂ­siÂ­cally routes your URL to the right hanÂ­dler. The API is very simÂ­ple, and will be strucÂ­tured as folÂ­lows:

  • GET /api/whiskies => get all botÂ­tles (getAll)
  • GET /api/whiskies/:id => get the botÂ­tle with the corÂ­reÂ­spondÂ­ing id (getOne)
  • POST /api/whiskies => add a new botÂ­tle (addOne)
  • PUT /api/whiskies/:id => upÂ­date a botÂ­tle (updateOne)
  • DELETE /api/whiskies/id => delete a botÂ­tle (deleteOne)

We need some dataâ€¦

But beÂ­fore going furÂ­ther, letâ€™s creÂ­ate our data obÂ­ject. CreÂ­ate the src/main/java/io/vertx/blog/first/Whisky.java with the folÂ­lowÂ­ing conÂ­tent:

package io.vertx.blog.first;

import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicInteger;

public class Whisky {

  private static final AtomicInteger COUNTER = new AtomicInteger();

  private final int id;

  private String name;

  private String origin;

  public Whisky(String name, String origin) {
    this.id = COUNTER.getAndIncrement();
    this.name = name;
    this.origin = origin;
  }

  public Whisky() {
    this.id = COUNTER.getAndIncrement();
  }

  public String getName() {
    return name;
  }

  public String getOrigin() {
    return origin;
  }

  public int getId() {
    return id;
  }

  public void setName(String name) {
    this.name = name;
  }

  public void setOrigin(String origin) {
    this.origin = origin;
  }
}

Itâ€™s a very simÂ­ple bean class (so with getÂ­ters and setÂ­ters). We choose this forÂ­mat beÂ­cause Vert.x is reÂ­lyÂ­ing on JackÂ­son to hanÂ­dle the JSON forÂ­mat. JackÂ­son auÂ­toÂ­mates the seÂ­riÂ­alÂ­izaÂ­tion and deÂ­seÂ­riÂ­alÂ­izaÂ­tion of bean classes, makÂ­ing our code much simÂ­pler.

Now, letâ€™s creÂ­ate a couÂ­ple of botÂ­tles. In the MyFirstVerticle class, add the folÂ­lowÂ­ing code:

// Store our product
private Map<Integer, Whisky> products = new LinkedHashMap<>();
// Create some product
private void createSomeData() {
  Whisky bowmore = new Whisky("Bowmore 15 Years Laimrig", "Scotland, Islay");
  products.put(bowmore.getId(), bowmore);
  Whisky talisker = new Whisky("Talisker 57Â° North", "Scotland, Island");
  products.put(talisker.getId(), talisker);
}

Then, in the start method, call the createSomeData method:

@Override
public void start(Future<Void> fut) {

  createSomeData();

  // Create a router object.
  Router router = Router.router(vertx);

  // Rest of the method
}

As you have noÂ­ticed, we donâ€™t reÂ­ally have a backÂ­end here, itâ€™s just a (in-â€‹memory) map. Adding a backÂ­end will be covÂ­ered by anÂ­other post.

Get our products

Enough decÂ­oÂ­raÂ­tion, letâ€™s imÂ­pleÂ­ment the REST API. We are going to start with GET /api/whiskies. It reÂ­turns the list of botÂ­tles in a JSON Array.

In the start method, add this line just below the staÂ­tic hanÂ­dler line:

router.get("/api/whiskies").handler(this::getAll);

This line inÂ­structs the router to hanÂ­dle the GET reÂ­quests on â€œ/api/whiskiesâ€ by callÂ­ing the getAll method. We could have inÂ­lined the hanÂ­dler code, but for clarÂ­ity reaÂ­sons letâ€™s creÂ­ate anÂ­other method:

private void getAll(RoutingContext routingContext) {
  routingContext.response()
      .putHeader("content-type", "application/json; charset=utf-8")
      .end(Json.encodePrettily(products.values()));
}

As every hanÂ­dler our method reÂ­ceives a RoutingContext. It popÂ­uÂ­lates the response by setÂ­ting the content-type and the acÂ­tual conÂ­tent. BeÂ­cause our conÂ­tent may conÂ­tain weird charÂ­acÂ­ters, we force the charset to UTF-8. To creÂ­ate the acÂ­tual conÂ­tent, no need to comÂ­pute the JSON string ourÂ­self. Vert.x lets us use the Json API. So Json.encodePrettily(products.values()) comÂ­putes the JSON string repÂ­reÂ­sentÂ­ing the set of botÂ­tles.

We could have used Json.encodePrettily(products), but to make the JavaScript code simÂ­pler, we just reÂ­turn the set of botÂ­tles and not an obÂ­ject conÂ­tainÂ­ing ID => Bottle enÂ­tries.

With this in place, we should be able to reÂ­trieve the set of botÂ­tle from our HTML page. Letâ€™s try it:

mvn clean package
java -jar target/my-first-app-1.0-SNAPSHOT-fat.jar

Then open the HTML page in your browser (http://localhost:8080/assets/index.html), and should should see:

Iâ€™m sure you are cuÂ­riÂ­ous, and want to acÂ­tuÂ­ally see what is reÂ­turned by our REST API. Letâ€™s open a browser to http://localhost:8080/api/whiskies. You should get:

[ {
  "id" : 0,
  "name" : "Bowmore 15 Years Laimrig",
  "origin" : "Scotland, Islay"
}, {
  "id" : 1,
  "name" : "Talisker 57Â° North",
  "origin" : "Scotland, Island"
} ]

Create a product

Now we can reÂ­trieve the set of botÂ­tles, letâ€™s creÂ­ate a new one. UnÂ­like the preÂ­viÂ­ous REST API endÂ­point, this one need to read the reÂ­questâ€™s body. For perÂ­forÂ­mance reaÂ­son, it should be exÂ­plicÂ­itly enÂ­abled. Donâ€™t be scaredâ€¦ itâ€™s just a hanÂ­dler.

In the start method, add these lines just below the line endÂ­ing by getAll:

router.route("/api/whiskies*").handler(BodyHandler.create());
router.post("/api/whiskies").handler(this::addOne);

The first line enÂ­ables the readÂ­ing of the reÂ­quest body for all routes under â€œ/api/whiskiesâ€. We could have enÂ­abled it globÂ­ally with router.route().handler(BodyHandler.create()).

The secÂ­ond line maps POST reÂ­quests on /api/whiskies to the addOne method. Letâ€™s creÂ­ate this method:

private void addOne(RoutingContext routingContext) {
  final Whisky whisky = Json.decodeValue(routingContext.getBodyAsString(),
      Whisky.class);
  products.put(whisky.getId(), whisky);
  routingContext.response()
      .setStatusCode(201)
      .putHeader("content-type", "application/json; charset=utf-8")
      .end(Json.encodePrettily(whisky));
}

The method starts by reÂ­trievÂ­ing the Whisky obÂ­ject from the reÂ­quest body. It just reads the body into a String and passes it to the Json.decodeValue method. Once creÂ­ated it adds it to the backÂ­end map and reÂ­turns the creÂ­ated botÂ­tle as JSON.

Letâ€™s try this. ReÂ­build and restart the apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion with:

mvn clean package
java -jar target/my-first-app-1.0-SNAPSHOT-fat.jar

Then, reÂ­fresh the HTML page and click on the Add a new bottle butÂ­ton. Enter the data such as: â€œJameÂ­sonâ€ as name and â€œIreÂ­landâ€ as oriÂ­gin (purists would have noÂ­ticed that this is acÂ­tuÂ­ally a Whiskey and not a Whisky). The botÂ­tle should be added to the table.

Status 201?

As you can see, we have set the reÂ­sponse staÂ­tus to 201. It means CREATED, and is the genÂ­erÂ­ally used in REST API that creÂ­ate an enÂ­tity. By deÂ­fault vert.x web is setÂ­ting the staÂ­tus to 200 meanÂ­ing OK.

Finishing a bottle

Well, botÂ­tles do not last forÂ­ever, so we should be able to delete a botÂ­tle. In the start method, add this line:

router.delete("/api/whiskies/:id").handler(this::deleteOne);

In the URL, we deÂ­fine a path paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­ter :id. So, when hanÂ­dling a matchÂ­ing reÂ­quest, Vert.x exÂ­tracts the path segÂ­ment corÂ­reÂ­spondÂ­ing to the paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­ter and let us acÂ­cess it in the hanÂ­dler method. For inÂ­stance, /api/whiskies/0 maps id to 0.

Letâ€™s see how the paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­ter can be used in the hanÂ­dler method. CreÂ­ate the deleteOne method as folÂ­lows:

private void deleteOne(RoutingContext routingContext) {
  String id = routingContext.request().getParam("id");
  if (id == null) {
    routingContext.response().setStatusCode(400).end();
  } else {
    Integer idAsInteger = Integer.valueOf(id);
    products.remove(idAsInteger);
  }
  routingContext.response().setStatusCode(204).end();
}

The path paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­ter is reÂ­trieved using routingContext.request().getParam("id"). It checks whether itâ€™s null (not set), and in this case reÂ­turns a Bad Request reÂ­sponse (staÂ­tus code 400). OthÂ­erÂ­wise, it reÂ­moves it from the backÂ­end map.

Status 204?

As you can see, we have set the reÂ­sponse staÂ­tus to 204 - NO CONTENT. ReÂ­sponse to the HTTP Verb delete have genÂ­erÂ­ally no conÂ­tent.

The other methods

We wonâ€™t deÂ­tail getOne and updateOne as the imÂ­pleÂ­menÂ­taÂ­tions are straightÂ­forÂ­ward and very simÂ­iÂ­lar. Their imÂ­pleÂ­menÂ­taÂ­tions are availÂ­able on GitHub.

Cheers!

Itâ€™s time to conÂ­clude this post. We have seen how Vert.x Web lets you imÂ­pleÂ­ment a REST API easÂ­ily and how it can serve staÂ­tic reÂ­sources. A bit more fancy than beÂ­fore, but still pretty easy.

In the next post, we are going to imÂ­prove our tests to cover the REST API.

Say Tuned & Happy CodÂ­ing !
